results.title: A Global market
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
The complex economic activities performed by humans takes on a new perspective when viewed from space with remote sensors. Important questions are posed. How does mining interfere with the lives of local inhabitants? Can the Earth really support its population? A global image illustrates how all the continents of the planet are linked by trade and shipping routes.

results.title: Restless rocks
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
From space, the way the continents fit together is apparent. The movements of continents set the stage for the present climatic epoch, with its particular distribution of mountain ranges and ocean currents. Satellites make possible the first global watch on volcanoes, from sparsely inhabited regions to the most populous areas.

results.title: Living quarters
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
An attempt to examine the impact of future human population growth. If the Earth’s population is set to double in the next few decades, how can it support this increase? Remote sensing allows scientists to see the patterns of population distribution across the globe as they detect the lights from cities and towns from space.

results.title: The New global geography
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Antelope Films and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Spaceship Earth”.
In conjunction with modern computing power, space technology is helping scientists to create global geography. The aim is to discover how Spaceship Earth’s life-support system really works, and how natural and human forces are changing it. Satellites help us to understand our planet, particularly in monitoring global weather patterns which can shift rapidly.

results.title: Rendezvous
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program examines the application of necessary physical laws to bring two orbiting space craft to a meeting in space. “Rendezvous” illustrates accomplishing a complete rendezvous manoeuvre when two spacecraft are in different orbits and on different planes.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.

results.title: Over the hill to the moon
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How does a spacecraft overcome the conflicting gravity pulls when travelling from earth to the moon? This program addresses this problem and also dramatises an entire lunar flight through the use of animation and exciting live footage.

results.title: Energy in orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
This program uses animated dramatisation to examine the characteristics of potential and kinetic energy, and the ways in which these forces affect a satellite’s orbit.

results.title: Principles of orbit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
How do the laws of inertia and universal gravitation govern the flight of an orbiting satellite? This program investigates the question by demonstrating the behaviour of a satellite, both in circular and elliptical orbit.

results.title: Flight to the planets
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Space Science”.
Examines both the principles that govern flight to the planets and the gravitational pull of each of the nine planets of our solar system.
